P atay2; 1 Le KremUn-Bicêtre/F, 2 Budapest/H Arteriovenous malformations (AVMs) of the brain are vascular lesions that can harbour different types (fistula o r nidus) o r different sizes (micro-AVMs (sm aller than 10 mm) o r macro-AVMS). They can be unique o r multiple (nearly 20% of cases in the pediatric population), even systematized (Wiburn-Mason syndrome). The revealing symptoms include intracranial hemorrhage (more than 50% ), seizures, progressive neurological deficits or headaches. Because of the poor natural history of brain AVMs, they are often proposed for treatment, and em bolization represents actually the best initial therapeutic management, either as sole treatm ent o r associated to surgery or radiotherapy.
body_text.section: B. Bronchial stenting D. Liermann; Frankfurt/D

body_text.text: The architecture o f the lesion represents the most im portant point that has to be studied in AVMs, as it will point to the weak portions of the network that will influence the clinical course. It is therefore im portant to analyse precisely the type of AVM, its location (best seen thanks to MRI) and its angioarchitecture. Till now only angiography has proven capable to determ ine the latter data. MRA has made trem endous progress thanks to new technical achievements and refinem ents (MOTSA, magnetization transfer, gadolinium injection...). Reported sensitivity and specificity are remarkably high. Nevertheless, the accuracy o f MRA remains inferior to that of angiography, and no therapeutic decision nor analysis of the "evolutivity" of the lesion can be made with that method. The most frequent sources of errors were superposition of vascular structures, signal loss due to saturation o r intravoxel dephasing artifacts, low signal due to incorrect velocity encoding values in PC MRA, and insufficient spatial resolution. However, MRA remains, if well-performed and analyzed, a satisfactory tool fo r confirmation or exclusion of such a vascular lesion. It appears to be a reasonable imaging, or screening alternative capable of providing diagnostic information with the necessary degree of confidence. C erebrovascular disease is uncommon in children. The incidence is believed to be around 2.5 cases per 100,000 population per year, excluding cerebrovas cular disease during the perinatal period. The causes of ischemic stroke in children are varied and quite different from those in adults. The imaging strategy is therefore different in children.
body_text.section: B. Bronchial stenting D. Liermann; Frankfurt/D

body_text.text: Despite aggressive investigation and modern imaging methods, the majority of children presenting with stroke will not have an identifiable underlying cause. The most common known cause of stroke in children is congenital heart disease with right to left shunt. Bacterial endocarditis and venous thrombosis can complicate congenital heart disease and play a etiological role in stroke.
body_text.section: B. Bronchial stenting D. Liermann; Frankfurt/D

body_text.text: Other im portant causes include coagulation defects, hematological diseases and certain metabolic syndromes such as mitochondrial encephalomyopathies, e.g. MELAS-syndrome. Vasculopathies are uncommon in children but Moya-Moya disease may occur in older children. Traum a, particularly to the neck region, may initiate dissection of the brachio-cephalic vessels and is the cause of stroke in 20% of adolescents presenting with stroke symptoms. Intracerebral hemorrhage can clinically present as stroke. Arterio-venous malformations and dural sinus thrombosis should be suspected. The primary goal fo r imaging of stroke in children is distinguishing between hemorrhagic and ischemic stroke as further diagnostic strategies differ sig nificantly. The secondary goal is to identify those causes in w hich available treatm ent options will influence the immediate or subsequent care fo r the child. However, the need for invasive diagnostic procedures m ust be assessed in the context of potential treatm ent options.

body_text.text: The com monest single indication for surgery in the pediatric population in England is for "glue" ear, where the normal ventilation of the middle ear cleft is replaced by tenacious secretion. This disorder and other com plications of middle ear sepsis are ultimately determ ined by dysfunction in the eustachian tube ventilation of the middle ear. W hilst "glue" ear does not require imaging, other com plications of chronic dysfunction, such as keratom a and mastoid infection, certainly do. The anatom y and physiology o f the middle and external ear will be described, with illustrative examples of the most important pathologies. Despite modem antibiotic therapies, intracranial com plications of both sinus and ear disease still occur and require careful investigation. Cochlea implantation is now performed fa r more frequently fo r senseorneural hearing loss and this requires assessment o f the ear both for structural abnorm alities and patency. Imaging of the ears and paranasal sinuses is, today, undertaken by cross sectional imaging using CT and MRI and these modalities will be used to illustrate the talk. The two-step, fluoroscopically guided technique fo r percutaneous nephrostomy will be shown and explained in detail. W ith the first step the renal pelvis is punctured from dorsal with a 23 " chiba needle and the obstructed system is opacified. In the second step a dilated posteriorly orientated calyx is punctured with a 19" Lunderquist needle with teflon sheath from a dorso-lateral approach. A flexible guidewire with rem ovable core is introduced into the renal pelvis and the catheter is advanced over the guidewire into the renal pelvis. Thereafter the flexible wire is exchanged for an extrastiff Amplatz wire. All further procedures are perform ed over this wire. The parenchymal tract is dilated stepwise up to 9 F and a 8 or 9 F pigtail catheter is inserted. The optimal position of the pigtail would be a dilated upper calyx.

body_text.text: The obstructed ureter is recanalized with a guidewire after percutaneous nephros tom y has been performed. Usually a Bentson or Terumo wire is used. W hen the bladder has been entered with the guidew ire a 5 F catheter is advanced over the wire into the bladder and an Amplatz extra stiff wire is introduced. Over this wire the double J-stent can be inserted. In case of very firm ureteral stenoses this stenosis can be predilated. However, the disadvantages include poor time resolution, patient access and equipm ent compatibility. A new generation of MRI systems and interventional tools are now becoming available which overcome many of these limitations. C hallenges for interventional MRI include visualisation of delivery devices such as biopsy needles. This has been addressed by combining multiple imaging modalities such as ultrasound and MRI and the investigation of novel materials and coatings fo r improved visualisation. body_text.text: Interventional procedures w hich can be monitored using MRI include laser and radiofrequency therm al ablation, photodynam ic therapy, cryo-therapy, high power focussed ultrasound as well as the use of interstitial chemical and radioactive agents. Organs w hich have been targetted include the liver, the breast, the prostate and the brain. A review of recent results obtained with this exciting new modality will be presented. The term "quality practice" in radiography implies that an acceptable level of professional standards is being met, and fo r many radiographers quality practice is synonymous with competence. However, unless one can specify w hat constitutes "com petence" , it is difficult to know w hat to expect. Therefore, making com petence explicit can allow a profession to publish statements about w hat their qualified members are com petent to do, and w hat people can reasonably expect of them. Ensuring that standards are easy to understand, also allows a decision to be made when incompetence occurs. A further advantage is that the standards (the separate elem ents of com petence) provide a foundation fo r curriculum devel opment and for the design o f valid assessm ent systems. Together with the competence required by a newly qualified radiographer fo r their first employ ment, the publication of standards can assist in the assessment of continuing competence. But how are standards derived? In addition to a review on competence, this presentation will first exam ine the m ethods w hich may be used to identify professional standards, and secondly will consider the techniques which can be employed to design valid assessment tools including the role of portfolios fo r both assessment and for continuing professional developm ent. In this way it is hoped to raise awareness on the im portant role that education plays in maintaining quality practice. Purpose: The detection of radiotransparent foreign bodies, w hich account for the majority o f foreign bodies (FBs) to be found in soft tissue, has always constituted a diagnostic challenge fo r the radiologist w ho is called upon to facilitate the task of the surgeon and the medical examiner, and represent a significant gap in conventional radiodiagnostic. We assessed the validity of US in the diagnosis of FBs. Materials and Methods: Five sam ples of bovine muscular tissue 5 cm thick was used. By making 5 mm surface incisions, 20 w ooden, plastic and glass FBs having diameters ranging from 1 x 1 mm to 1 x 10 mm were introduced at various distances apart. Working independently and blindly, three ultrasographers evaluated the presence and size o f fragm ents, using a 7 .5 -1 0 MHz linear probe. Methods and Materials: radiography in tw o projections fo r 302 patients with direct repeated enlargement of image was carried out by apparatus " REIS" and "Electrónica 100D" (Russia). The aim of this prospective study w as to evaluate the role o f a fast, whole body helical CT scanner fo r prim ary diagnosis in traum a patients. Materials and Methods: 27 severely injured patients (9 women, 18 men; mean age 43 years) were first exam ined with a helical CT scanner allowing for digital radiogramms up to a length of 1024 mm and continous helical scans of up to 70 seconds (slice thickness 3 to 10 mm, pitch factor up to 2). The primary CT diagnosis was proofed either by X-ray after the C T examination or within the following day, by abdominal ultrasound, by additional CT scans in the following days and by clinical follow-up. Results: CT detected all clinically relevant injuries of the head, spine, chest and abdomen. The diagnosis and classification of vertebral fractures and their am ount of damage to the spinal cord was performed immediately. 4% of the fractures o f the extremities and the ribs were not seen primarily. 6% of the injuries were out of the CT scan field. Conclusion: Helical CT is a reliable and fast method of obtaining vital infor mation and of improving m anagem ent planning, in severely injured patients. It reduces the number o f conventional X-ray exam inations and can replace ab dominal sonography. In certain cases additional X-rays of extremity fractures are required. , wrist (n = 8), ankle and foot (n = 16), knee (n = 11) and hip joint (n = 3), were examined by thin-section CT including multiplanar and 3D-reconstruction. Multiplanar reconstructions (MPR) were performed in two predefined perpendicular planes. 3D surface reconstructions were optimized fo r fracture visibility. The im pact of conventional radiographs, axial CT and MPR on final diagnosis and therapeutic management as well as the value of 3D-reconstructions fo r treatm ent planning w as assessed by two board-certified traum a surgeons. Results: In 37/45 patients (82%), axial CT provided informations not available from conventional radiographs, resulting in a change in therapeutic manage ment in 9 patients (20%). Endorectal MRI is highly operator-dependent, and interobserver variations are frequent, particularly in case o f multi-institutionnal study. Interpretations made in a single institution, by radiologists very fam iliar with endorectal MRI yield a better specificity. Finally, radical prostatectomy specimen is an im perfect "gold standard" because incision of the prostate capsule is common during surgery precluding correct pathological staging. Despite its limitations, endorectal MRI improves the preoperative staging of prostate cancer as it identifies 50% of patients who have clinically occult extraprostatic disease, thus reducing the preoperative understaging rate by half. In experienced hands, it can detect, fo r a given individual, extraprostatic invasion with extremely high specificity, ensuring that few, if any, patients will be deprived o f curative surgery. This lecture reviews these two form s of allergic lung disease. Eosinophilic pneum onia or pulmonary eosinophilia is a diverse group of disorders characterised by pulm onary infiltrates which are rich in eosinophils. There is alm ost always an associated peripheral blood eosinophilia and an increase in the num ber of eosinophils in bronchoalveolar lavage fluid.

The eosinophilic pneumonias are difficult to classify but the following are those which are usually recognisable clinically and radiologically: Simple pulm onary eosinophilia, tropical pulm onary eosinophilia, allergic bron chopulm onary aspergillosis, acute eosinophilic pneumonia, chronic eosinophilic pneumonia. The characteristic radiographic and CT appearances will be dis cussed.

Extrinsic allergic alveolitis is caused by the repeated inhalation of articulate organic antigen. The particles are very small and reach the terminal bronchi oles and alveolar ducts where they are responsible for a respiratory bronchilitis and alveolitis. The disease is normally divided into acute, subacute and chronic forms, depending upon the timing and severity of exposure and onset of the disease. Each give characteristic radiographic and HRCT patterns.

1385 Pneumonia in the im munocom petent and im munocom prom ised patient G. Gavelli, M. Zompatori, R. Canini, F. Celletti, G. Battista; Bologna/I Infective pneum onitis are one of the most im portant causes of morbidity and mortality. Clinical suspicion of pneum onitis is a common motivation to the radiological evaluation. It is im portant to differentiate com munity and nosocomial pneumonitis and pneumonitis in im munocompetent and immunocompromised patients. The role o f radiology may be sum marized as follow:

(1 ) Defining presence, site and extension o f thoracic pathology. False negative findings are rare but possible in early stage of diffuse pulm onary infection as PC in AIDS patients and miliary tuberculosis: X-ray findings appear later in com parison to clinical symptoms but HRCT or Ga 67 scintigraphy are able to visualize pulm onary involvement in early stage.
(2) Stating if radiological pattern is com patible with infective pneumonitis.

Differential diagnosis between infective pathology and other lesions is difficult. It is im portant to correlate clinical and radiological findings. (3) Detecting predisposing factors as other infections, aspiration or obstructing bronchial cancer. (4) C hest X-ray and mostly CT may indicate the site of the lesion and suggest the m ost useful technique to obtain diagnostic specimens. (5) C T is the optimal technique to diagnose associated pathology and com pli cations: abscess, septic embolism, ARDS, pneumothorax, bronchiectatis, gangrena, pleural effusion, em physema, bronchopleural fistula, adenopa thy. (6) To evaluate drug therapy efficacy. Functional MRI studies may also be employed in certain circumstances; they may conceivably indicate the potential for visual recovery.
1387 Infectious diseases of the brain C.F. Andreula; Bari/I

The involvement of the Central Nervous System along the course o f infectious diseases causes different clinical, anatom opathological and neuroradiological aspects, due to the different microbical agents, to their virulence and the efficacy of the Immunitary System of the host. Brain infections are distinguished according to the life period occurring: lesions affecting the foetus in the first and second trim ester of pregnancy with organogenesis disturbances and consequent m alformations, and infections of the late pregnancy, perinatal period, childhood and adulthood. Lesions are divided in diffuse and focal ones. The diffuse ones are: meningitis, meningo-encephalitis and encephalitis. Acute meningitis are alm ost always neuroradiologically negative. In Chronic meningitis the most frequent is the tubercular granulom atous form, then Mycosis as Cryptococcosis and Coccidioidomicosis. Neuroradiology monitor the com plications of meningeal infec tions, such as severe hydrocephalus, ventriculitis, subdural effusions infections and cerebrovascular complications. Among Congenital Encephalitis the most frequent infections contracted dur ing the pregnancy are listed below the acronym TORCH. Among the Periand Post-natal encephalitis we should report Herpes Simplex type 1 Virus acute meningo-encephalitis and acute dissem inated encephalomyelitis with demyelinating "plaques". Chronic encephalitis is very uncommon. The focal lesions are cerebritis, immature form, and abscess and granuloma, m ature form s and cysts. The agents responsible for abscesses are bacteria. The agents responsible fo r granulom as are mycobacteria, fungi, and protozoa (toxoplasma). Parasitic cysts are related to Echinococcosis, Cisticercosis and Cryptococcosis.

S 2 7 4 8:30-10:00 Magnetic resonance (MR) have greatly advanced both the understanding and the diagnosis of pediatric pathology. In order to maximize the information, high-quality images m ust be obtained. In pediatric patients motion during imaging sequences produce artifacts that may simulate pathologic conditions. Adequate sedation or general anesthesia eliminate the gross body motion. The effects of the physiologic random o r periodic motion artifacts (i.e. bowel peristalsis or cardiac pulsation) can be controlled with a variety of techniques, including respiratory and cardiac gating, к -space phase reordering, gradient moment nulling, and even echo rephasing. Fast and reduced-acquisition ma trix Fourier-acquired steady-state (RAM-FAST) techniques allow acquisition of a set of images in less than 30 sec. Ultrafast techniques virtually eliminate all motion at the expense of a poor S/N ratio. Other artifacts may simulate pathologic conditions and produce pitfalls in the interpretation o f MR images (aliasing, truncation, chemical shift and magnetic susceptibility artifacts), in cluding those related to the use of MR angiography. W ith an understanding of MR physical principles, instrumentation and techniques artifacts can be identi fied, corrected, minimized, or avoided. Moreover, in pediatric MR, the imaging parameters for the acquisition o f optimal images differ from those of the adult because standard adult imaging sequences do not consider the changing appearance of the developing brain and bone marrow. An understanding of these physiological variations with age is also im portant in examining MR pattern and determining w hether they are potential disease process or normal variations.

1389 Doppler ultrasound In the pediatric abdomen Z. Harkányi; Budapest/H Pediatric vascular imaging using ultrasound has become an essential part of abdominal studies. Recent observations indicate the usefulness of Doppler US in the detection of increased or reduced vascularity of the bowels in certain disorders. Congenital vascular anomalies can be diagnosed with the combination o f conventional US imaging and duplex-Doppler method. New ultrasound techniques have been introduced: color Doppler imaging (GDI), color vascular imaging (CVI) and C VIQ (volume flow measurement), color am plitude imaging (CAI) (or power Doppler) (to detect slow flow). The possible impact of the new techniques will be discussed. Indications of abdominal Doppler ultrasound studies will be summarized: Liver/biliary: portal hypertension, portal thrombosis liver masses, liver trans plant, acute cholecystitis; R enal: renal artery stenosis, inflammatory diseases, renal masses; Bowel: appendicitis, inflammatory bowel disorders (Crohn's dis ease), intususception; Vessels: aneurysm , congenital anomalies, thrombosis (IVC, aorta, iliac). In some cases color Doppler US is sufficient to establish the diagnosis, in other cases we can select the patients fo r other vascular imaging studies (e.g. MRA, СТА, angiography). Vascular ultrasound seem s to be an excellent, non-invasvive and cost-effective means to increase the confidence of the diagnosis. Limitations of the applications: operator dependency of abdominal Doppler examination and the need of respiratory cooperation. In shunt stenoses, balloon dilatation is the basic technic for most lesions and offers a technical success com parable to surgical interventions. In com plex cases, stent placement is required. Primary cum ulative shunt patency after stenting was 76% after 6 and 56% after 12 months. Due to reintervention, overall shunt function was 88% after six and 86% after 12 months. Atherectom y may be used in selected cases o f stent restenosis. Cutting PTA is a promising technique for resistant stenoses showing a 100% technical success and no particular complications. In shunt thrombosis, mechanical throm bectom y is an alternative to lysis. We performed 51 hydrodynamic thrombectom ies. Arterialized flow was reestab lished in 46 o f 51 procedures (90%). Early rethrombosis occurred in six cases within 24 hours post throm bectom y (11%). Clinical success was achieved in 39 o f 46 technically successful cases (85%). Cumulative patency was calculated S275 Friday 63% after 1 week, 57% after 1 months, 37% after 6 and 32% after 12 months. Similar results are achievable by other system s such as the Amplatz impeller. Thus, both fo r shunt stenoses and thromboses, successful percutaneous techniques are available.

Direct antegrade puncture o f the brachial artery is the preferred vascular ac cess fo r angiography o f failing haemodialysis fistulas. Angiography via brachial artery access gives more information about flow situation, morphology and hemodynamic significance of a stenosis than any other angiographic technique especially retrograde angiography with suprasystolic pressure cuff. Direct an tegrade puncture opens several possibilities for percutaneous transluminal angioplasty (PTA) in the arterial part, the anastom osis and the distal and even the proximal venous outflow o f an arterio-venous fistula. The advantages and disadvantages o f this technique will be discussed with several examples of PTA. All material which is necessary fo r this intervention will be demonstrated and the procedure will be explained in detail.

body_text.text: The purpose of our w orkshop is to demonstrate our current technique of angioplasty of hemodialysis fistula. W e will focus on technical points based on Video dem onstration including various clinical cases. We use a direct puncture o f the fistula using a 18G Teflon needle. A soft tip guide wire is used to cross the stenosis and a 6 F introducer sheath is introduced. A 20 to 30 mg bolus of heparin is recommended, lowering the risk o f throm bosis. The sheath allows less trauma to the skin entry point and facilitates control angiograms. Living a > 1 cm subcutaneous tract between the entry point in the fistula and the skin puncture is a valuable method to prevent late false aneuyysm. The size o f the balloon is usually from 6 to 7 mm for PTFE grafts and from 5 to 12 o r 14 mm according to the size of the vessel to be dilated in fistulae. Slight overdilation is possible. The systematic use of a m anom eter is mandatory in order to avoid balloon rupture in very strong stenoses. Regular PTA balloons are to be used on the first intention but in about 10% of cases, the stenosis will resist to 15 atm and a high pressure balloon (Blue Max, Olbert) should be tried. In some cases however, failure can occur due to stronger stenosis. Photon Emission Tomography, SPECT, functional Magnetic Resonance Imag ing, fMRI). 1399 Interventional radiology (part II) C.L. Zollikofer; W interthur/CH Interventional radiology may be devided in into tw o large categories, vascular and non vascular interventions. A) Vascular interventions deal mainly with recanalisation procedures i.e. per cutaneous transluminal angioplasty (PTA) of arterial and venous obstructions. There is a vast num ber o f instruments being used ranging from steerable guidewires and various balloon catheters to devices fo r mechanical recanal isation such as aspiration catheters, various types o f drills and atherectomy catheters. For acute occlusions pharmacological thrombolysis and/or mechan ical thrombectomy devices may be used. On the other hand em bolisation procedures are performed to occlude abnormal or bleeding vessels such as in trauma, tumor, ulcers, infection o r arterial venous malformation and aneurysms. B) Non vascular procedures include mainly percutaneous biopsies fo r diagnos tic workups and drainage procedures such as abscess drainage or drainage of the biliary and urinary system. Lately endolum inal stents are increasingly used for palliation of strictures of the esophagus, stomach, duodenum and colon. The radiographer in the interventional room should be fam iliar not only with the various procedures but also with the instrumentation, patient monitoring and in most frequently used drugs in these procedures. Examinations performed in the radiology departm ent expose the patients to significant risks due to limitations in monitoring and therapy during transport and examination. Therefore, bedside im aging modalities such as plain radiog raphy (including special views) and ultrasonography are particularly important. The patients' cooperation is usually severely compromised, affecting image quality and diagnostic value of otherwise established examinations. Fast imaging modalities are required to overcome motion artefacts and decrease overall examination time. Life support devices may degrade image quality and even preclude specific examinations. Therefore, in these patients C T is usually superior to MRI. Imaging may be required out o f office hours performed by staff with limited experience. Modalities with unrestricted availability may thus replace dedi cated procedures (e.g. Spiral-CT versus pulm onary angiography in suspected pulmonary embolism). This presentation will deal with com m on diagnostic problem s and an approach to the optimum use of imaging procedures in ICU patients.

Imaging of abdominal and pelvic em ergencies either traum atic on nontraumatic has undergone marked changes in the last decade. Comm only performed ad ditional imaging studies, including ultrasonography and com puted tomography, enable many underlying causes to be diagnosed promptly, more accurately and less invasively, thus contributing to a decrease in mortality rates. Precise clinical history and thorough physical examination are, however, necessary to tailor the diagnostic approach to the individual patient. Plain abdominal radiographs remain the initial examination in acute nontrau matic abdominal conditions and may be m andatory in intestinal obstruction, when careful and methodical interpretation is exersised. Ultrasonography has shown to be extremely accurate in depicting abdominal absesses or intraperitoneal, pararenal o r perihepatic fluid collections. It can also diagnose acute cholecystitis and acute appendicitis, while it demonstrates parenchymal changes in traum atic abdom inal conditions. Computed tom ography offers the advantage of a simultraneous comprehen sive evaluation of both solid and hollow viscera in inflammatory, neoplastic and vascular disorders. It has revolutionized the evaluation o f patients with intestinal obstruction, allowing an accurate diagnosis, by defining the location and the likely cause and suggesting the presence of intestinal ischem ia or strangulation. Acute cholecystitis, abdominal abscesses, pancreatitis, pelvic inflammatory disease and acute mesenteric ischem ia are additional diagnostic posibilities fo r which CT has gained wide acceptance. C ontrast enchanced CT studies have also proved the diagnostic approach of choice in evaluating stable patients with blunt abdominal trauma. Over the years trauma has become one of the leading causes of mortality, especially fo r the younger population. Moreover, the socio-econom ic impact with al kinds and grades of disability, long hospital stay, and expensive rehabilitation is a trem endous burden for the society. Despite these facts, modern and appropriate trauma m anagem ent has not been discussed and taught too often in lectures, meetings o r symposia.

1405 Major vascular injury in traum a: Influence o f new technology S.E. Mirvis; Baltimore, MD/USA This presentation addresses developm ents and controversies o f the last decade concerning the imaging assessment o f blunt traum a patients with potential traum atic aortic injury (TAI). The lecturer will briefly describe the "natural history" o f acute TAI as it relates to the diagnostic work-up and initial management. The appropriate plain radiographic interpretation of the chest radiograph as a baseline screening study for detection o f mediastinal hemor rhage is em phasized, including the use o f "true erect" positioning. The role of contrast-enhanced C T scan as an ancillary screening technique, particularly since the advent o f spiral technology and power-injected intravenous contrast boluses, will be considered with demonstration of the various C T findings associated with major thoracic arterial injury. The sensitivity, specificity, and predictive value o f CT, as well as its cost-effectiveness as a diagnostic tool for aortic injury is presented. Some limitations of thoracic angiographic diagnosis, the standard reference technique, will be illustrated and quantified. Finally, brief consideration will be given to the potential value of transesophageal echo (TEE) as a new diagnostic procedure and how it might fit best into the diagnostic work-up o f patients with blunt chest trauma.

1406 Role of digital radiology W. Hruby; Vienna/A Traum atology is a speciality which is heavily relying on radiological informa tion of various sources, such as plain X-ray images, com puted tomography angiography, interventional radiology, magnetic resonance imaging or ultra sound. This implies a close co-operation between the traum atologist and the radiologist.

The reliable availability of radiological information as well as its fast transfer a n d com m unication to the places where needed is of crucial importance for an efficient patient care and management. The hospital m ust be equipped to perform the above mentioned modalities and staffed with experienced radiologist to run and interpret these modalities. Traum a centres effectively reduce morbidity and mortality of the accident patient.

In 1995 the following percentages of patients referred to radiological exami nations by the traum a-centre were found 6% in US, 12% in CT, 11% in MRI, 11% in radiological-interventional procedures, 16% in chest-X-rays and 80% in skeletal exam inations (plain films). A s com puter technology and information sciences have made their impact on office automation and everyday Business, they also are increasingly applied in medicine and in particular in radiology. After several year of laboratory experimentation together with the radiologists of the Danube Hospital in Vienna, the operational implementation of filmless digital radiology in clinical routine w as world-w ide first possible in April 1992 at this hospital. Filmless digital radiology means a digital netw ork that interconnects radiologi cal equipm ent with diagnostic reporting workstations, with digital archives and with viewing stations on w ards and in outpatient clinics, where images and report can be retrieved on-line, without the need of searching fo r paper or films.

Methods and Materials: 100 patients (1 9 -7 6 y) presenting low back pain or sciatica were studied with CT. Keulers, R.W. Günther; Aachen/D Percutaneous diagnostic interventions in the thorax are widely accepted as useful procedures with high diagnostic efficacy and low com plication rate. The success of these procedures depends largely on the exact detection and localisation of lesions in all thoracic com partments including the chest wall, on the exact planning of the intervention and the correct verification o f the needle tip during the procedure. In this regard computed tom ography is the superior imaging modality for guiding percutaneous diagnostic interventions of the chest, whereas the value of fluoroscopy and ultrasound is limited. The needle selection depends on the location and suspected nature of the lesion.

Langer; Osnabrück/D Purpose: Prospectively to examine the value of different imaging m ethods in suspicious breast lesions and to calculate their diagnostic im pact by a logistic model and ROC-analysis. Materials and Methods: Quantitative contrast-enhanced MR-m amm ography (flash-2-D) and color Doppler quantifying num ber and flow of vessels have been performed in 68 patients (mean age 54.4 (3 2-83 ) years) w ho presented with suspicious breast lesions in palpation, X-ray-mammography, o r ultrasound (7.5 MHz). Diagnostic performance was com pared by ROC-analysis. Results: The com bination o f focal SI-increase of > 70% 1 min after in travenous Gd-DTPA [MRM: weightening factor 3], > 6 vessels within or around a focal lesion [color Doppler: w eightening factor 2.1] und suspicious mammographie sign [weightening factor 2] diagnosed 96% of lesions correctly. Material and Methods: W e collected over an 18-months period the CT files of all patients w ho had a diagnosis of strangulation confirmed at surgery. This group of 8 patients w as com pared to a control group o f 37 patients with non-com plicated adhesive small bowel obstruction. The presence of the following features w as assessed in a prospective manner in both groups: mural thickening, target sign, intramural haemorrage, reduced mural enhancement, mesenteric congestion, mesenteric fluid, ascitis, peritoneal gas. The CT signs were correlated with the surgical findings. Laparatomy w as carried out in 24 patients, because o f failure o f the medical treatm ent (n = 10) o r presence of clinical and/or radiological signs of com plications (n = 14). Results: CT affirmed o r suspected a strangulation in 12 patients, all part of the group not treated medically in the first instance (sensitivity 100%, specificity 89% ). Abnorm al enhancem ent w as present in 2/8 patients in the strangulation group, 0/37 patients in the control group, the triad of mural thickening + mesenteric fluid + mesenteric congestion in 4/8 and 2/37 patients, ascitis in 7/8 and 12/37 patients respectively.Conclusion:Reduced enhancement o f the bowel wall and the triad of mural thickening + mesenteric fluid + mesenteric congestion are highly suggestive of strangulation and should prompt rapid surgery.583 Value of CT as a primary diagnostic procedure in sm all bowel occlusion M. Conclusion: MR-urography could be proposed as a new diagnostic modality for the evaluation of renal collecting system in patients with renal lithiasis before ESWL.11:35 626 Functional MR urography for the assessm ent o f renal transplants M.V. FIGREF157.text: Ureteral pseudodiverticula: A preneoplastic lesion? P. Pavlica, L. Barozzi; Bologna/I Purpose: Ureteral diverticula belong to the group of acquired diverticula even if their pathogenesis and clinical significance are still a subject o f dispute. They are occasionally detected during urography o r retrograde urogram and appear as small spicular o r saccate outpouchings of the wall, single o r more often multiple, limited for the most part to the upper third of the ureter. The frequent association of these lesions with transitional cell carcinoma of the urinary tract is a problem of great clinical interest since they could represent a premalignant manifestation. Material and Methods: We report on 16 patients with pseudodiverticula: all were males over 46 years. They were studied with urography and 6 with retrograde pyelography. Results: Ureteral involvement w as bilateral in 50% o f patients, 4 of whom were affected by sinchronous o r metachronous vesical neoplasia. The radio logical picture shows small marginal outpouchings 1 -3 mm in diameter. Their demostration require a good contrast opacification and distension of the ureter. Conclusion: The reported observations confirm data in the literature on the high association between pseudodiverticula and transitional cell carcinoma. These patients may thus be considered a risk group fo r neoplasia, even if no precise confirmation exist that these hyperplastic alterations always precede onset o f tumor. Patients with pseudodiverticula of the ureter therefore require careful clinical-radiological control with a view to detecting early signs of malignant metaplasia. Mitchell; Chapel Hill, NC/USA Purpose: To demonstrate the MR appearance o f focal hepatic lymphoma.Methods and Materials: Eighteen patients with hepatic lymphoma (6 primary, 12 secondary) were imaged at 1.5 T. T1-weighted and T2-w eighted images were performed in all patients. Immediate and 5 -1 0 minute delayed T1weighted spoiled gradient echo images were acquired in 15/18 patients. Results: Focal lesions of hepatic lymphoma were well defined m asses with mild to m oderate low signal intensity relative to liver on T1-w eighted images. Lymphoma lesions in eight patients were moderately high in signal intensity on T2-weighted images com pared to liver (Type I lesions). Six of these patients underwent gadolinium administration, and enhancem ent o f lesions w as intense on early post gadolinium images in five of these patients. Lym phom a lesions in seven patients were mildly hypointense to mildly hyperintense on T2-weighted images compared to liver (Type II lesions). Six of these patients underwent gadolinium administration, and lesions in five of these patients enhanced minimally on the early post gadolinium spoiled gradient echo images. The imaging findings in 3/18 patients w ho were already on therapy were variable. Transient ill-defined perilesional enhancement on immediate post gadolinium spoiled gradient echo images w as observed in 9/14 patients w ho underwent gadolinium administration. Conclusion: Focal lesions of hepatic lymphoma are usually low in signal inten sity on T1-weighted images but have variable signal intensity on T2-weighted images. The degree of hyperintensity on T2-w eighted images correlates with the degree of enhancement.11:15 652 The pseudocapsule in hepatocarcinoma (HCC): MR findings related to pathological features L. Bartoli; M arseille/F Purpose: Twenty percent o f local recurrence after high-dose radiotherapy of nasopharyngeal carcinom as (NPC) justify systematic follow -up essentially in patients initially staged T3 -T4.The purpose o f this study is to assess the role o f medical imaging in the multidisciplinary follow -up o f these patients. Methods and Material: Thirty-nine cases of NPC treated from 1989 to 1994 were retrospectively reviewed, including clinical, endoscopic, patho logic records, CT-scan and MRI exam inations performed during follow-up. All patients benefited of contrast enhanced CT-scan o r MRI at least every 6 months.Results:The volum e regression and contrast-enhancement decreasing in stages T 3 -T4 were inconstant and often incomplete, even with negative biopsies. T1-weighted MRI showed spontaneous hypersignal in prevertebral muscles due to fatty involution. MRI allowed biopsies to doubtful tissue invisible with endoscope in 4 cases. It detected 4 recurrences in paracavernous sinus o r submucosal location. Conclusions: In spite of difficulties to interpret residual foci of contrast enhancement, MRI seems essential to oversee tum or regression, detect early recurrences and guide biopsies. Perineural infiltration in nasopharyngeal carcinoma V.F.H. Chong, Y.F. Fan; Singapore/SGP Purpose: Nasopharyngeal carcinoma (NPC) frequently spreads intracranially. This study describes the utility of MRI in the identification of intracranial spread as a result o f perineural infiltration. Methods and Materials: O ne hundred and fourteen consecutive patients with proven undifferentiated NPC were evaluated with T1-, T2-weighted and contrast-enhanced MRI and CT. Results: MRI showed 35 (31%) patients intracranial extension. Of the subset of 35 patients with intracranial spread, 21 (60% ) patients showed involvement of the maxillary nerve (4 patients, 11%) and the mandibular nerve (17 patients, 49%). CT could identify 26 (23%) patients with intracranial spread. C T identi fied foramen rotundum widening in 3 (9%) patients and erosion of the foramen ovale in 12 (34%) patients. Conclusion: NPC shows a high incidence o f maxillary and mandibular in filtration and subsequent intracranial spread. This is best identified directly by contrast-enhanced MRI. CT under estim ates the frequency o f intracranial extension via perineural infiltration.10:50659 Anterior neopharyngeal diverticulum -A possible cause of postlaryngectomy dysphagia C. Oursin, P. Fournier, G. Pitzer, G. Bongartz, W. Steinbrich; Basel/CH Purpose: Aim of this prospective study was to determ ine the frequency of anterior neopharyngeal diverticulum formation as a possible cause of postoperative dysphagia in 18 laryngectomized patients. Methods: All patients were examined by indirect laryngoscopy and a barium swallow. Results: Six patients com plained of postoperative dysphagia. Indirect laryn goscopy showed a tissue band, separating the diverticulum from the neophar ynx, in all symptomatic as well as in three asymptomatic patients. The barium swallow confirmed all diverticula suspected during laryngoscopy, in five patient additional diverticula were diagnosed. Conclusion: Anterior neopharyngeal diverticula occur frequently after laryn gectomy (78% of our patients), not necessarily causing clinical symptoms. The most important indication to perform a barium swallow in patients with post operative dysphagia is the differentiation between tum or recurrence and other etiologies of dysphagia. If an anterior neopharyngeal diverticulum is present, the barium swallow demonstrates the size o f the diverticulum, a possible reten tion after swallowing and rarely an obstruction of the pharyngeal lumen during deglutition. For this reason dysphagia in laryngectomized patients needs fur ther diagnosis with a barium swallow. In this context the radiologist must be aware of diverticulum formation, an entity poorly recognised until now.

Dalla Palma; Trieste/IThe term "acute renal infection" encom passes a spectrum o f pathologic processes involving the renal parenchyma that vary in severity from acute pyelonephritis to a renal abscess w hich can progress to the peri-and pararenal spaces. The clinical pattern of all the pathological variants is quite similar: therefore if it is easy to diagnose a renal infection, it is impossible to recognize the pathological variant and its extension. The imaging modalities may solve this problem. Most risk factors of acute renal infection can be elicited by a good clinical history and physical examination. Due to the low sensitivity of IVU, renal scintigraphy (99mTc-labelled DMSA) and US should be the first exam inations to be performed. Their limitations are due to the incomplete evaluation o f the process, mainly in cases of extrarenai extension. CT is the study of choice to define the pattern of renal involvement and extrarenai extension, intra-o r extrafascial. CT is also useful in understanding the pathophysiology o f the infection using precontrast and postcontrast, early and delayed scans. The imaging modalities are indicated:(1) when the disease is resistant to medical treatment (2) w hen predisposing factors are present (urinary tract stones, indwelling urinary catether, vesicoureteral reflux, neurogenic bladder, diabetes and immunodeficiency) (3) For follow-up under medical treatment (4) To guide drainage in com plicated cases which do not respond to antibiotic therapy.712 B. Children M.H. Smet; Leuven/B Urinary tract infections remain am ong the m ost common bacterial infections in children. Renal scarring from recurrent infection is an im portant cause of end-stage renal disease and hypertension in the pediatric population. Main risk factors fo r developm ent of pyelonephritic scarring are obstructive malformations, vesico-ureteral reflux, young age and delayed or insufficient therapy. Imaging diagnostic techniques are of param ount importance fo r evaluation of the child with urinary tract infection and identification o f those at risk for infection. Only early diagnosis and prompt institution of proper therapy reduce the likelihood of renal scarring and hence, improve child's outcome. In this course, the current status of the pathogenesis o f acute renal infection in children and available imaging m ethods will be discussed. FIGREF203.text: Mediastinal masses: Diagnostic approach F. Laurent; Bordeaux/F Mediastinal masses remain an important challenge fo r the radiologist. This presentation focus on the role of imaging in the diagnostic approach of me diastinal masses in an adult population. Chest radiograph remains the first modality performed in the detection of mediastinal abnorm alities but specific clinical situations lead to further imaging evaluation. C om puted tom ography especially with spiral acquisition is today the next step with a high powerful role in characterization and planning therapy. Magnetic resonance imaging, ultrasound, and thransthoracic needle biopsies have specific indications. Dif ferential diagnosis is presented according to the main imaging findings as fatty, cystic solid and vascular masses.763 Imaging of the m ediastinal vessels D. Hahn; Wurzburg/D MRI of the mediastinal vessels is very well established since many years. MR-imaging of the mediastinum already allowed a very good evaluation of diseases of the thoracic vessels using spin-echo sequences. Especially diseases of the thoracic aorta, inflammatory as well as degenerative changes, can be evaluated with a very high diagnostic accuracy. Mediastinal veins were causing more problem s because of the slow flow. The imaging quality of the pulmonary arteries is beating all other conventional or digital imaging procedures. The improvement of MR, especially of MR-Angiography, nowadays allows an excellent imaging of the mediastinal arteries and veins in a 3-D-mode. For 3-D-imaging of the thoracic vessels normally tim e-of-flight techniques are applied. Phase contrast sequences should be the prim ary method used, if blood flow measurements are requested. The additional use of paramagnetic contrast medium can improve the signal to noise ratio and the imaging quality. Most of these examinations can be done in breathhold-technique. Conclusion: MRI and MRA nowadays should be the primary methods for the evaluation of diseases of the thoracic vessels. Especially MRA can provide functional data in thoracic aneurysm s and stenoses. Invasive examinations should only be done if MR is not able to establish a correct diagnosis. Diagnosis and treatm ent of cerebral AVM A. Valavanis; Zurich/CH

Rosa; Naples/I Purpose:to evaluate diagnostic accuracy of Fast 3D SPGR Fat Suppressed tecnique in the identification and grading of chondral knee lesions, com pared to arthroscopic results. Methods and Materials: 29 patients performed MR exam ination between August 1995 and February 1996 integrated by 3D Fast SPGR Fat Suppressed pulse sequence. This sequence was performed in 12 patients at fem orotibial level, in 10 patients at the patello-femoral joint, in 7 patients in both compartments. All patients underwent subsequent arthroscopic examination. Results: the lesions were graded according to Noyes classification. MRI provided the following results: Grade 0 = 8 pts, Grade 1 = 7 pts, Grade 2 = 9 pts, Grade 3 = 5 pts. MRI Grade 3 lesions were all confirmed at arthroscopy. MRI overestimated 3 of the 9 Grade 1 lesions because o f artifacts, misinterpreted as surface fibrillation. 3 MRI Grade 1 lesions were found normal at arthroscopy. All grade 0 lesions were arthroscopically confirmed. Conclusions: MRI provided a high-negative predictive value in the identifica tion of chondral knee lesions, with no false-positive results. MRI accuracy in the diagnosis of presence o f pathology is 89.6% . while in grading chondral knee lesions the accurancy is 79.3%, overestimating early stages of pathology.

Apter; R am at Gan/IL Purpose: Intussusception in adults is nowadays usually diagnosed on CT, as CT is often the first modality fo r the investigation of prolonged abdominal pain, from which these patients suffer. W e wish to present the CT, clinical and pathological findings of 16 adult patients with intussusception seen over a 5-year period. Material and Methods: The abdom inal scans of 16 patients with intussuscep tion were reviewed. Special attention was directed to the location of the mass, its shape and fat content, possible underlying pathology and dilatation o f the bowel proximally. The findings were correlated with clinical and pathological data. Results: There were 8 men and 8 women, aged 34-81 years. The most frequent indication fo r CT was prolonged abdom inal pain. C T findings included an inhomogeneous soft tissue mass, target or sausage-shaped, depending on the angle of the CT beam versus the intussusception with a fatty component in 14 of the 16. Intussusception w as enteroenteric(6), ileocolic (3) o r colocolic (7). Complete small bowel obstruction w as present only in one case and some bowel dilatation in 3. The underlying pathology could be diagnosed on CT in 2 cases of lipoma. Nine patients had an underlying m alignant process, 8 of them unsuspected. Of the other 5, 2 had celiac disease, 2 w ere classified as idiopathic and one had a necrotic polyp o f undeterm ined pathology. Conclusion: Intussusception on CT presented a characteristic mass lesion containing fa t stripes in almost all patients. Obstruction was rarely seen. Bartolozzi; Pisa/I, 1 Livom o/I Purpose: To determ ine the role of 3-D phase contrast MR angiography data processed with phase difference technique in assessment of vascular anatomy o f spinal arterio-venous malformations. Methods and Materials: Seven patients with angiographically proved spinal artero-venous m alform ations were included in the study. They underwent Gd-DTPA enhanced MR angiography (Signa 1.5 T, GE/Medical Systems) with the 3-D phase contrast technique and phase difference reconstruction. Images acquired have been processed with a SunSparc workstation (Advantage W indows, GE/Medical Systems), using the Voxtool software. The first step was volum e rendering of data to enhance pixels with Maximum and Minimum Intensity Projection algorithm s (MIP and MinIP). The second step w as to select the pixels enhanced with a thresholding segmentation. The relative voxels were rendered to obtain a 3D solid model of the malformation. Results: The 3D models obtained with the thresholding selection provided useful information about the anatom y o f the spinal vascular malformations. Furthermore, the application of oblique and curved cut planes, to eliminate the background and obtain a subvolume of the builded model, makes easier the evaluation of malformations characteristics. Heller; H eidelberg/D Purpose: Evaluation of 3D-M agnetic resonance (MR) Myelography (3D-MRM) compared to transaxial and sagittal T1-und T2-weighted magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) in the diagnosis of lumbar spine disease. Material and Methods: 75 patients with symptoms of spinal canal stenosis or discogenic degenerative disease of the lumbar spine underwent preoperatively diagnostic transaxial and sagittal MRI studies and 3D-MRM examinations.Each method was interpreted separately by blinded observers. The surgical findings were considered to be the "gold standard". Results: Compared to surgical findings, correct diagnosis was made on transaxial and sagittal MR images in 69/75 patients (92%). On 3D-M RM the pathologic changes were diagnosed correctly in 68/75 patients (90.6%). 3D-MRM and MRT combined predicted the surgical findings in 71/75 patients (94.6%) correctly. Conclusion: 3D-MRM is a non-invasive and fast procedure which produces images comparable to conventional myelography. In com bination with T1 and T2-weighted MR-imaging this technique improves diagnostic accuracy in lumbar spine disease. Bjerknes; Oslo/N Purpose: To assess the diagnostic efficacy, safety and tolerability of MnDPDP in liver MRI. Materials and Methods: Two open Phase III, non-com parative, studies in 624 adult patients were performed using lesion count as main parameter. Patients with 1 -5 liver lesions were included in the study. To evaluate safety and tolerability, patients were followed fo r 24 hours, and adverse events w ere recorded, a total of 621 patients w ere imaged before and after the administration o f MnDPDP at a dose o f 5 μ mol/kg b.w. T 1 -weighted SE and GE sequences and a T2-weighted SE sequence were performed pre-contrast; the T1-W sequences were repeated post-contrast. Results: Comparing the maximum num ber o f lesions seen post-versus pre-MnDPDP, more were seen post-MnDPDP in 17% o f the patients. The differ ence in the favour o f the post-examination was statistically significant (p = 0.0001, McNemar test), although the T2-weighted sequence w as not repeated post-contrast in m ost patients. Of the 624 patients who received MnDPDP, 26 (4%) experienced infusion-associated discom fort and 46 patients (7%) reported a total of 63 adverse events. Only 16 of these events were related to MnDPDP. Conclusion: The results show that MnDPDP is safe and well tolerated and useful for detecting additional liver lesions. Novak; Jerusalem /ILPurpose: To determ ine if discriminant analysis applied to com puter extracted quantitative features of clustered micro-calcifications (CMC), on digitized screen-film mammograms, can be used as a classifier. Materials and Methods: Using pathology records, archival cases o f biopsy proven CMC identified on screen-film mammogram s were sequentially chosen fo r analysis. Seventy-seven cases were included, 37 benign and 40 malignant. The area of abnormality was identified by an experienced m am m ographer and this region was digitized to 0.04 mm pixel and 8 bit depth, using a flat bed CCD scanner. A software program was developed to allow the m am m ographer to interactively target the individual calcifications on the digital image. The software automatically extracted features characterizing both the individual micro-calcifications and the structure o f the cluster as a whole. The most significant features were used for pattern recognition based on discrim inant analysis. Each case was classified using the Jack-Knife technique. ROCanalysis was used to evaluate the performance of the procedure. Results: Eight parameters were found to be significantly related to the biopsy results (p < 0.005). The area under the ROC curve was 0.875. Conclusion: Pattern recognition using autom atically extracted quantitative features fo r CMC on screen-film mammograms, w as found to be a useful method for classification.10:45 871 Autom atic detection of clustered m icrocalcifications in digitized mamm ograms T. Peitgen; Brem en/D Purpose: A novel, straightforward method fo r the autom atic detection of clustered microcalcifications in digitized mammogram s is proposed and its performance com pared to a well-established Bayesian approach. Material and Methods: The detection scheme uses a multiscale analysis based on the Laplacian-of-Gaussian and a m athem atical model describing a microcalcification as a bright spot o f certain size and contrast. For the evalu ation of the detection performance the method is applied to 40 mammogram s (Nijmegen database, 100 micron pixel size, 105 clusters marked by expert radiologists, images are rescaled to equalize image noise). R esults are pre sented in FROG curves plotting the num ber of true positive detections as a function o f the false positive detections. The FROG curves are com pared to the results o f a Bayesian approach using the same database. Results: Both methods have a com parable detection perform ance even though fundam ental different approaches are used. The multiscale m ethod is simpler and does not rely on additional training images. Conclusion: The rather simple multiscale method discussed here performs very well, com pared to a more elaborated approach. Materials and Methods: Seventy-four patients with clinically isolated neuro logical symptoms suggestive o f MS were studied with MR. Receiver operator characteristics (ROC) analysis was used to determine the optimum cut-off point fo r each criterion, and logistic regression to remove redundant information and built a diagnostic model. Results: Clinically definite MS developed in 33 patients (prevalence 45%). The median follow -up in those patients not converting was 39 months. All MR vari ables were dichotom ized at the optim um cut-off (9 for total number of lesions, 3 fo r periventricular lesions, 1 for most others). Since backwards analysis in addition identified infratentorial and periventricular lesions, a final model w as built using 4 variables, which had a strongly positive predictive value (92% ) fo r conversion to clinically definite MS (Mantel-Haenszel, p < 0 .000001).Conclusion: A 4 param eter dichotomized model including gadolinium en hancement, juxtacortical, infratentorial and periventricular lesions strongly predicts conversion to MS. 14:35 969 The effect of training on reporting gadolinium-enhancing MS lesions F. FIGREF338.text: Instability in the upper extremity A. Blum, V. Metz; Nancy/F, Vienna/AAnterior instability is the most common of all glenohumeral instabilities. Glenoid fracture, ligam ent and capsular lesions are responsible fo r recurrent instability. Other lesions are consequences of instability and affect the bones o r the cartilage (humeral defect, greater tubercle fracture, coracoid fracture) and soft tissues (labral tear, rotator cuff tear). Posterior dislocations are uncommon but often misdiagnosed. 50% of the posterior dislocations are diagnosed when fixed. Recurrent posterior instability is m ost often volontary. Carpal instability is a disturbance of the normal balance o f the carpal joints caused by fracture or ligam entous damage. The loss o f normal alignm ent of the carpal bones may develop early or late. If undiagnosed, carpal instability can lead to pain, disability and osteoarthritis. Carpal instability can be analyzed according to 6 categories: chronicity, constancy, etiology, location, direction and pattern. We will expose the new concepts about instability of the shoulder and of the wrist and discuss the role of each imaging method (plain films, stress views, athrography, CT-arthrography, MRI and M R-arthrography) in the diagnosticai strategy. 1602 C urrent M R-techniques in breast diseases Chairperson: B. ISBERG (Huddinge/S)1074 A. Clinical indications and resultsR. Gilles; Le Krem lin-Bicêtre/FThese last 10 years, breast MR imaging has been extensively studied. The results o f all these series agreed in the high sensitivity o f breast MRI for detecting invasive breast cancers (sensitivity: 95%). Therefore, the absence of early contrast enhancem ent after injection o f gadolinium can exclude a suspicion of malignancy with a high level o f confidence (false negative, 5%). However, its specificity reported varies between 40 and 97% . The diagnostic value of quantitative analysis of contrast enhanced lesions is a subject of controversies. Therefore early contrast enhancem ent is not synonym ous of malignancy (false positive, 5 -60% ). Breast MRI has proved to be useful in some difficult diagnostic problem s to exclude breast m alignancy especially in palpable breast masses associated with dense breast on mammograms, and local relapses. Some series have emphasized the high accuracy o f breast MRI S 213 to determ ine the extent o f either invasive or in situ breast carcinomas, and the response o f breast neoplasm to chemotherapy. These have to be confirmed in larger series. Breast MR imaging have proved useful in the follow up of women with silicone breast prostheses. The sensivity and specificity for diagnosing intra-capsular ruptures are 76% and 95% respectively. In conclusion, breast MR imaging offers trem endous potential in the diagnosis and localization breast cancers.1075 B. Technical aspects S.H. Heywang-Köbrunner, R. Beck, P. Viehweg; Halle/D Purpose: Different examination technique, different interpretation criteria and different patient selection influence the results o f contrast-enhanced MRI of the breast. Technical factors which may influence detection and diagnosis of small lesions in particular will be discussed. M ethods and Material: Our experiences are based on the examination of alm ost 3000 MR breast exam inations and on phantom studies, which had been perform ed to optimize MR technique fo r an international breast MRI study. Results: A significant im pact on the diagnostic accuracy is demonstrated for the choice of slice thickness, the choice of pulse sequence (signal response versus tissue concentration of Gd-DTPA), the choice of echo time (opposed versus in phase imaging) patient motion and its effective elimination, mode of fat suppression (spectral selective fat saturation versus subtraction). Further effects concern imaging time, timing of injection, way o f evaluation. The chosen evaluation criteria m ust allow a sensible com prom ise of a high sensitivity and acceptable specificity. Conclusion: Knowledge and awareness of potential pitfalls in technique and evaluation are fundam ental fo r reproducible high quality and clinically useful results. Diagnostic approach to pancreatic tum ors (part I) H.-J. Brambs; Ulm/DDuctal adenocarcinom a of the pancreas continues to have a poor prognosis because of late clinical symptoms. C T and MRI are the m ost common techniques fo r evaluating patients with suspected pancreatic tum or and can contribute to the diagnosis and staging of this disease. W ith refined helical CT scanning techniques and fast MRI techniques the evaluation of early and limited disease can be improved. The diagnosis of pancreatic tum or is based on changes in the density, texture, and contour of the pancreas associated with secondary signs such as dilatation o f the pancreatic and bile ducts and changes in the surrounding fat tissue and the peripancreatic vessels. Helical CT can accurately define the extent of vascular involvement and correctly predict the resectability in the vast majority of patients. Because both methods, CT and MRI, depict the bile and pancreatic ducts sufficiently, ERCP is restricted to selected cases. Three-dimensional helical CT arteriography can display vascular anatom y accurately and can replace conventional angiography in assessing hepatic and mesenteric arterial and portal venous anatomy. Endocrine tum ors of the pancreas are rare neoplasm s that cause distinct clinical syndromes. Many radiological techniques are recommended fo r tumor localization, including ultrasound, endoscopic ultrasound, CT, MRI, angiog raphy, and venous sampling. However, the choice of preoperative imaging continues to be controversial and depends on local expertise and availability of imaging techniques. Recent publications give rise to the recommendation of MRI as the technique of choice to detect small endocrine tumors.

FIGREF341.text: Congenital malform ations of the spine and spinal cord O. Flodmark; Stockholm/S Malformations of the spine may involve mesodermal as well as neuroecto derm al structures. The investigation o f patients suspected o f having a spinal malformation should focus first on evaluation of the neurogenic tissues in order to confirm or exclude a malformation. Then, further investigations must concentrate on a full and detailed mapping of all com ponents of the m alfor mation allowing the neurosurgeon to plan reconstructive surgery with all facts available in order to avoid com plications due to poor understanding o f the malformation. For this purpose, the radiologist must possess full theoretical knowledge o f pathology and em bryology of each malformation. The purpose of the investigation in patients with myelomeningocele, open dysraphism , is primarily to detect postoperative com plications related to the m alformation. O ther forms o f spinal dysraphism are characterized by a more or less intact skin, closed spinal dysraphism.This group o f malformations include entities that may cause neurological, urological and orthopedic problem s in children and young adults. Cutaneous m anifestations of the underlying malformation are common and may be present in addition to, or without other clinical symptoms. Early corrective surgery of these malformations is thought to prevent developm ent of new symptoms and halt progression of those present. Hence, suspicion o f closed spinal dysraphism should result in early referral to a neurosurgeon followed by radiological evaluation, even if the neurologic examination is normal. Such an investigation must have a very high sensitivity and specificity and be carried out with utmost care. in infancy and childhood is significantly different from such infection in adults in clinical features and in long-term com plications based on anatom ic differences, such as the peculiarity of the vascular patterns and the presence of growth mechanisms which are prone to be severely dam aged by infectious disease. Real time provides physiologic information o f the vessel wall com pliance and flow dynamics. Advantages o f C.T. angiography over con ventional angiography are diminished patient mobility, cost and physician time requirement. M archai3; 1 B asel/C H ,2 Utrecht/NL, 3 Leuven/B The basic requirements for C T angiography are the rapid and continuous acquisition of high resolution volum etric data during the first pass of the contrast bolus in the vessels and appropriate postprocessing. The vascular contrast is function of slice thickness, table pitch, the recon struction algorithm, the size and angle of the vessel, the degree o f vascular enhancement and the attenuation o f the surrounding tissues. MR-angiography has become a widespread method throughout the many imaging centres. The hitherto mostly applied technique is Time-of-Flight (TOF) MRA with the benefits o f being fast, well resolved, semi-selective due to spatial presaturation capabilities, and applicable to several anatom ical areas. Phase Contrast (PC) demonstrates good results in slow flow conditions and allows flow measurements. Contrast-enhanced MRA (СЕ-MRA) relies on a com bination of a peripheral injection of contrast agent with a very fast TOF acquisition technique. Though similar to CT-Angiography СЕ-MRA benefits from liberty in image orientation, and stronger sensitivity to contrast media. Besides reconstruction of CE-MRA angiograms is more easy in areas adjacent to bone. Because o f the rapid improvements of the techniques their respective role has to be reassessed. Casselman; Brugge/B CT is very useful fo r the demonstration o f tem poral bone fractures. The main plane is transverse or horizontal showing in 90% of the cases a longitudinal extralabyrinthine fracture with an entrance in the pars squam osa or mastoid. The labyrinthine lesions are transverse originating in the occipital bone. The incus is usually damaged in the long process with o r without dislocations. The stapes may be involved with vestibular luxation, fracture of the footplate and/or lesions o f the annular ligament. CT may also be perform ed in the detection of traum atic labyrinthine fistula particularly through the oval and round windows. In case of post-traumatic nerve paralysis, a hematoma in the course o f the nerve can be detected on MR and the damaged nerve segm ent is sometimes seen as a thickened enhancing region. More over only MR can show the proximal and/or distal extend of the nerve oedema, showing the surgeon that the decompression should be wider. MR can also help in the differentiation between an encephalocele and other tissue o r fluid when a tegm en fracture occurs. MR is also the only technique able to dem onstrate intralabyrinthine hemorrhage (on unenhanced T 1 -weighted images) or fibrosis (on gradient echo images) in case of labyrinthine concussion. The inflam matory changes developing during the days following the occurrence of a perilymph fistula can sometimes be recognized as an intralabyrinthine enhancem ent on MR. Hunink; Groningen/NL T he decision to implement a new medical technology involves a trade-off between the risks and benefits to the patient as well as a trade-off between the potential effectiveness to be gained and the limited resources at hand. The unique feature in the technology assessment of diagnostic tests is that the results of such tests are intermediate outcomes implying that the effectiveness gained in term s o f improved survival o r quality o f life, and the potential cost savings, are largely an effect o f the treatm ent strategy chosen on the basis of the test results. Both randomized controlled clinical trials and decision analysis have an im portant role to play in the assessment of diagnostic tests. Important points to consider when performing a cost-effectiveness study are posing a well-defined question, what perspective to take, com paring the technology to the next best strategy, including both effectiveness and costs, distinguishing between describing and valuing the quality of life, taking into account intangibles such as the value o f information, the incremental costeffectiveness ratio, and performing a sensitivity ("what-if?" ) analysis.

TABREF79.text: Child abuse is the major cause of serious intracranial injury in infancy. The socio-econom ic implications are often profound with varying degrees of physical and mental handicap. Neuroimaging should be integrated into the clinical, social and medicolegal assessment o f each case. Mechanism s: 1) Im pact Injury: blows inflicted on head; head struck against a surface (including bedding). 2) Shaking: (whiplash effect): rapid accelerationdeceleration and torsional forces. 3) Suffocation: intentional or unintentional obstruction of airways. Imaging: 1) S keletal survey. 2) H igh resolution ultrasound. Screening tool, highly sensitive fo r delicate contusional injuries, extra-axial collections and fol low up imaging. 3) C TM andatory for acute injury. Most reliable and sensitive to acute intracranial haemorrhage. Cerebral oedem a detected early (4 -6 hours). Less sensitive for subtle parenchymal injuries and extra-axial collections. 4) M R I High sensitivity for parenchymal injuries, extra-axial collections, blood products, ischaemic sequelae. Timing of Imaging: Image as early as possible. Follow up imaging is essen tial fo r secondary and late sequelae (long term prognosis and medicolegal purposes). Patterns o f Injury: 1) Acute Impact -scalp haematoma, skull fractures, subdural and subarachnoid haemorrhages, cerebral contusions and lacera tions. Shaking -subdural haematoma, diffuse axonal injury, contusional tears. 2) Secondary Ischaemic damage, hydrocephalus, cerebral oedema. 3) Late Atrophy, chronic subdural collections, brain herniations, skull vault maldevelopment.

Bartolozzi; Pisa/lPurpose: To evaluate local therapeutic effect and long-term survival rates after combined transcatheter arterial chem oem bolization (TACE) and percutaneous ethanol injection (PEI) fo r single, large, hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). Methods and Materials: Eighty-six cirrhotic patients with single, large (3 -8 cm) HCC underwent combined TACE and PEI over a 6-year period. All patients were in Child-Pugh class A o r B. Patients were followed after therapy by m eans of clinical examinations, laboratory tests, and US and CT studies performed at regular time intervals. Survival rates were determ ined according to the Kaplan-Meier method. Results: No major com plication was observed. A com plete therapeutic re sponse was obtained in 71 (82%) of 86 patients. The overall survival rates w ere 92% at 1 year, 83% at 2 years, 69% at 3 years, 58% a t 4-years, and 47% at 5 years. Survival of Child-Pugh A patients w as significantly longer (p < 0.01) than that of Child-Pugh В patients. The survival rates of patients with HCC o f 3 -5 cm were higher than those o f patients with HCC of 5 -8 cm, although the difference was not statistically significant (p > 0.05) Conclusion: Combined TACE and PEI is a highly effective treatm ent for single, large HCC. Methods and Material: The study com prises 27 patients with malignant ob structions of the common bile duct. None of them was a surgical candidate. Patients with hilar lesions were excluded. Hatjikondi, P. Ravazoula, T. Petsas, D. Siamblis, E. Tzorakolefterakis, J. Dimopoulos; Patras/GR Purpose: In a previous study, in rats with experimental liver metastases, we found that Color Doppler Vascular Studies can clearly depict hepatic haemodynamic changes related with the presence of early, neoplastic cell deposits. The purpose of this prospective study is to determ ine the alterations that Adriamycin may induce in the liver haemodynam ics of these animals. Materials and Methods: Two groups o f W istar rats, with experimental liver metastases (Walker 256 carcinosarcoma), are used in this project. In the first group, Adriamycin is injected as a single IV dose of 20 mg/kg on the 5th day of metastatic process, while in the second group an identical dose is given on the 7th day of metastatic disease. Eventually each group is divided into two subgroups and Doppler measurements (consisting of Doppler Perfusion Index [DPI] of the liver and Portal vein and Hepatic artery Flow Volume [PFV, HFV]) are obtained one day (1st subgroup) and three days (2nd subgroup) after the drug injection. All livers are examined histologically soon after each measurement. Other factors such us liver parenchymal oedema and inflammatory process as well as cardiotoxicity due to the chemotherapeutic agent and their haemodynam ic influence are also under long term investigation in our study. Results: Thirty six animals have been studied so far, 20 in the 1st group (11/9 in subgroups) and 16 in the 2nd (9/7 in subgroups). In all livers Adriamycin provoked strong suppression and decrease of the metastatic cells to a level similar to the early metastatic infiltration of the liver connective tissue by isolated cells. The haemodynam ic indices, in both groups, show a characteristic fluctuation with tendency of normalization of the DPI and PFV values one day after drug administration and return to abnormal levels three days after. The variance o f these values found to be significant (p values: 0.0254 and 0.0128 respectively). In contrast, HFV values have not shown yet significant differences. Conclusion: Our initial results strongly suggest that liver haemodynamic indices are not only good predictors o f occult hepatic metastases, but they may also monitor the drug activity on liver metastatic disease. Methods and Materials: Low contrast resolution constitutes one of the basic performance parameters of Computed Tomography systems. MASCIOCCHI (L'Aquila/l) 1203 Overload disorders in sports activities (sum mary) C. Masciocchi, L. Zugaro; L'A quila/lIn athletes, osteochondral, tendineous and synovial pathologies can occur as result of biomechanical overload. The stress fractures occur as a consequence of microtraumatic events and biom echanical overload. If misdiagnosed, these lesions are cause of painful syndrome and functional disability. Conventional techniques such as plain films and C T allow a good evaluation of stress fractures; MR imaging has proved to be particularly accurate in the diagnosis, especially fo r the early evaluation o f bone edema on T2 weighted sequences. Concerning osteochondral diseases, from the ethiological point of view, the biomechanical overload seems to be the main cause. Functional overload induces changes both in the cartilaginous com ponent and the subchondral bone. The knee and subtalar joints can be usually affected by osteochondral pathology. MRI has a higher sensitivity in identifying such pathological con ditions over other imaging techniques including CT, which, although able to visualize severe alterations, does not allow evaluation o f early subchondral le sions. Meniscal tears represent the most common cause of pain and functional disability o f the knee in athletes. B etter than other diagnostic techniques, MRI allows visualization of such structures on axial and longitudinal scan planes. Due to high spatial and contrast resolution and multiplanar imaging it is possible by means of MRI to distinguish different types of meniscal lesion. Tendinous diseases are common occurrences in sports. The "overuse injuries" are the most frequent to record as a consequence of repetitive microtrau mas. Tendon injuries can further be divided into acute, subacute and chronic. Tendon's injuries sites change in connection to the different sport practised. Synovial pathology may be the effect of overload o r repeated microscopic le sions. Acute o r chronical synovial disease concerning joints, bursae o r tendon sheaths, if not diagnosed, are causes o f athletic capacity reduction. Available imaging methods in tendinous and synovial disease include ultrasound, CT and MRI. MRI has the greatest potential utility in the evaluation o f tendon because o f its numerous advantages.
