TABREF170.text: 1207 Fibrocartilaginous and chondral disease M.T. McNamara; M onte Carlo/MCMagnetic resonance (MR) imaging is well suited to imaging joints. It is the only noninvasive imaging method which is capable of depicting joints and their various components, including fibrocartilage and hyaline cartilage. Conventional pulse sequences may be utilized to visualize fibrocartilage, the most common being the menisci in the knees and the shoulder glenoid labrum. However conventional pulse sequences offer relatively poor image contrastfor articular cartilage and poor sensitivity fo r the depiction o f diseased cartilage. An improved discrimination of the state o f articular cartilage may be obtained by utilizing newer pulse sequences. An important cause of knee pain is hyaline cartilage defects. Such pain may be confused clinically with meniscal pathology. Recent advances in imaging of such lesions has em ployed fat-suppressed spoiled gradiant-echo (SPGR) and subtraction magnetization-transfer contrast-enhanced (STS) se quences. These techniques depict hyaline cartilage with positive contrast (higher signal intensity) relative to adjacent structures. Encouraging results have been demonstrated for imaging hyaline cartilage defects in the knee us ing thin-partitioned three-dimensional (3D) SPGR imaging. Saturation transfer is designed to selectively saturate short T2 species with restricted mobility associated with macromolecules, resulting in decreased signal intensity of cartilage, thereby increasing contrast-to-noise ratio between cartilage and joint fluid. Compared to conventional pulse sequences these tw o techniques have demonstrated superior depiction of articular cartilage lesions, showing good corroboration with arthroscopy and gross specim ens. Detection of hyaline car tilage abnorm alities is im portant because they may only otherwise be detected arthroscopically. Since newer therapeutic options are now available MR may play an important role in the noninvasive diagnosis and follow -up of such lesions. Tendinous degeneration A.M. Davies; Birmingham /UK Tendons are the tough inelastic, cords o f fibrous tissue that connect muscles with the structures to be moved, such as the bones and cartilages. Acute tears most com monly occur at the osseo-tendinous junction and are frequently accompanied by a small avulsion fracture. Less com monly tears occur at the musculo-tendinous junction. Chronic injuries also occur at the osseo-tendinous junction but may arise within the substance of the tendon itself. Before the advent of cross-sectional imaging little interest was paid to tendon pathology. Identification o f tendon abnorm ality relied on secondary signs such as avulsion fractures or indirect imaging with tenography o r bursography. Brambs; Ulm/D Purpose:The present paper attem pts to differentiate the osseous and softtissue m anifestations of alveolar echinococcosis (AE). Patients: We report on eight patients with AE with bone or soft tissue involvement confirmed at biopsy or needle cytology.Results: All eight patients with AE showed hepatic involvement. Four of eight patients with AE exhibited infiltration o f the spine as a result o f direct spread of the hepatic primary lesion; distant m etastases were observed in only three of these patients. Calcifications, w hich are typical for hepatic m anifestations of the disease, were observed in soft tissue in only tw o of eight cases (25%); we observed no instances of endovesicular daughter cysts. Conclusion: Alveolar echinococcosis manifests itself in the vertebral column as a form of spondylitis and in soft tissue presents similar to an abscess. Kazantseva, V.A. Isakov, V.l. Nefedova, E.V. Chikunova; M oscow/CISGastric cancer is still one of the highly ranked malignancies with high mortality rate. For increasing the efficacy of diagnosis we have analyzed the results of our screening program. During the 15 years we have examined 36000 patients from the risk groups who were included into the screening program for gastric cancer. The screening program included classic gastric radiography (tight filling and double-contrast) every year with subsequent endoscopy with multiple biopsy where needed. In difficult fo r interpretation cases we used dynamic CT with air distention o f the stom ach. 680 gastric cancers were found. 170 patients (25%) had early gastric cancers with size less than 3 cm. 120 (70.5%) of these patients had type lib (flat) lesions which were the most difficult to detect by endoscopy (only in 15 patients endoscopic diagnosis was correct). In most of these patients small contour irregularity during the tight filling radiography was the only feature to suspect gastric malignancy. In 118 of 120 patients dynamic CT o f the stomach with air distention revealed local S244 thickening of the stomach wall. The size o f the tum or determ ined by CT was totally confirmed in 106 patients by surgery, so the predictive value of CT with air distention was 89.8%. In the rest 12 patients C T decreased the real size of the tumor, probably, due to inadequate stomach distention. In conclusion, the type lib (flat) lesion is the most frequent type o f early gastric cancer. These tumors are the most difficult fo r endoscopic diagnosis, so the classic gastric radiography (tight filling and double-contrast) and if necessary subsequent CT with air distention of the stomach are the methods of choice in diagnosis of such tumors. Emmrich; Leipzig/D P urpose: To evaluate spiral CT in patients with suspected gastric cancer (g.c.). Methods and Materials: 234 patients underwent contrast enhanced Spiral CT. Results: A lesion was prospectively found in 95.9% of cases with g.c. (in 63.2% of early g.c.). The lesion was suspicious for g.c. in 91.8%. Compared with histology, there was a correct T staging in 83% (in 92.7% of pT3/pT4) and a correct N staging in 89%. A lesion by lesion analysis of regional lymph nodes (n = 51) showed that in spite of the reached accuracy only 65% of all lymph nodes were visible by CT. The M staging by CT was correct in 12 of 16 cases. Differences in enhancement of g.c. were found according to classification by Laurèn. CT and endoscopy showed a sensitivity o f 91% and 99% and a specificity of 90% and 40% in diagnosis of g.c.Conclusion: Spiral C T clearly improves the preoperative staging of g.c., especially in advanced cases. TABREF187.text: Chairperson: E.M. LAASONEN (Tampere/FIN) 1386 Imaging in neuro-ophthalmology I. Moseley; London/U K A prime indication for imaging in neuro-ophthalm ology is visual loss. Effective imaging must be tailored to the clinical pattern of visual loss. For presumed ocular causes, sonography is the investigation o f choice, followed in some cases by MRI. Optic nerve lesions can som etimes be localised clinically to the intraocular, intraorbital, intracanalicular or intracranial portions o f the nerve. CT and/or MRI may be combined to clarify the nature and extent of involvement. When optic neuropathy is part of a more generalised disorder, such as multiple sclerosis, w ider imaging of the CNS may be necessary. Vascular accidents involving the eye and optic nerve require reliable noninvasive imaging of the extracranial cervical arteries. Modern noninvasive imaging techniques show intracranial aneurysm s large enough to compromise the visual pathways; intra-arterial studies are indicated only fo r therapy. This may not apply to some low-flow arteriovenous m alfor mations o r fistulae interfering with vision, for which detailed superselective diagnostic studies may be required. MRI is the first-choice technique for lesions o f the intracranial optic pathways.

Purpose: Our aim was to treat single > 3 cm., or multiple hepatocellular carci nomas (HCCs) by interstitial laser photocoagulation (ILP) alone o r associated with trans-arterial chemo-embolization (TACE). Methods: Twenty patients with HCCs (52 lesions, diam eters: 2 0 -6 0 mm.) were treated by ILP. A 1.06 д т Nd:YAG laser coupled with 300 д т quartz fiberoptic guide advanced in a 21 G needle. Laser was fired for 8 -1 0 minutes (5 -1 0 W). Each lesion received 4 -1 0 treatm ents in 2 -5 sessions. TACE was performed on the lesions showing areas of viable tum or not treatable by further ILP. During follow-up (1 2 -1 8 months) CT and US were repeated every 3 months. Results: Post-treatment CT scan and core biopsy demonstrated com plete necrosis in the lesions < 3 cm (28 lesions) and variable degree of necrosis in the lesions > 3 cm. After TACE residual neoplastic tissue showed lipiodol retention. During follow -up period lesions treated by ILP and TACE were stable while 3/7 lesions > 3 cm. treated only by ILP showed local recurrence managed by further ILP. Conclusion: ILP is effective in treating small HCCs. In large o f multifocal HCCs it is useful in reducing neoplastic volum e and the num ber of viable lesions and, consequently, the required am ount of chem oem bolic agents and the number o f hepatic segments needing treatment. 1499 Embolization therapy of neoplastic lesions using a new embolic m aterial without antineoplastic agents K. Minamitani, S. Hori, K. Osuga, A. Okada, S. Kawata; Osaka/J Purpose: To develop an effective intervention of neoplastic lesions using a newly devised em bolic material without antineoplastic agents. Materials and Methods: Super absorbent polymer microsphere (SAP-MS, sodium acrylate and vinyl alcohol copolymer) was used as the embolic mate rial. It passes through a m icrocatheter and increases in size within minutes, when it contacts with serum. The size of microsphere is exactly calibrated us ing sieves in 50 micrometer steps. No toxicity was revealed in animal studies. Seven patients with benign lesions (5-kidney, 2-miscellaneous) and 12 patients with malignant lesions (4-kidney, 3-bone metastases, 2-liver, 3-miscellaneous), including 7 patients with preoperative state, were treated transarterially using various sizes o f SAP-MS without anti-neoplastic agents. In 4 patients, resected specim ens were evaluated histopathologically. To reevaluate cardiac MR imaging with regard to the phased array coil and newer pulse sequences in com parison to fast helical CT Methods and Material: Various fast and ultrafast MR-imaging strategies have been tested in 19 patients with inflammatory (n = 4), neoplastic (n = 12) and congenital (n = 3) pathology of the heart. The diagnostic outcom e of MRI was com pared with informations obtainable by fast helical-CT performed with 0.75 sec./revolution, 5 mm collimation, pitch 1 and 180° interpolation algorithm. Results: T2-weighted and STIR-contrast images with suppression o f blood signal are most suitable for cardiac screening. Gadolinium uptake fo r further mass characterization o r therapy-monitoring can be assessed with a multi-slice 300 m s SR (saturation recovery) turboFLASH sequence. To further delineate the mass location, contractility of myocardium and shunting breath-held movie loops obtained with segmented turboFLASH sequences are mandatory. Conclusion: Ultrafast MRI affords a detailed morphological and functional analysis o f the heart. W ithin 30 minutes of examination time several m ajor fac tors in the evaluation of pathology can be assessed: morphology, tissue water content and gadolinium perfusion/uptake of masses, myocardial contractility and flow dynam ics in the vessels as well as shunt directions and volum es through septal defects. Except for the pathognom ic depiction of calcifications and for the capability o f multiplanar reconstruction, cardiac MRI is superior to fast helical C T in the trade off between spatial, temporal and contrast resolution.
